author: sky.cactus
content: <@!332923501079953409> I *think* that the transaction pool problem is out of scope for 2718, but it is very much in scope for new transaction types.  That is, if some future transaction type changes the way gas price is determined (such as 1559) then that definitely needs to be thought about and potentially addressed in that EIP.  However, I don't believe that we can define a single consistent solution to that problem in 2718 that we can be sure will work for all possible future transaction types, since there isn't a hard requirement that future transaction types treat gas the same as legacy transaction types.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you disagree I would love to heard the argument.  I haven't thought a whole lot about this particular problem, but after you brought it up I spent some time thinking about it and that is where I landed.

author: iannorden
content:
The way I was thinking about it was that we could still have a transition period (hard fork 1) where both types are accepted, and gas is gradually shifted towards 1559. This period would, perhaps, allow us to guage the sentiment towards and behavior of the 1559 transactions before fully commiting to them. Then we switch to another period (hard fork 2) where only 1559 txs are accepted on chain but the clients handle any remaining conversion from legacy to 1559 to support any stragglers. And then a final (optional?) phase (soft fork) where that conversion is no longer needed because we assume everybody has switched over and the clients begin rejecting legacy txs.

One issue that becomes apparent with that line of thinking as I type it out is that if the eth client handes the tx conversion, there is less motivation for people to ever switch over to 1559 on their end. And we do want them to switch over, because simply setting tx.feeCap to the legacy gasPrice is not the efficient gas market behavior we are looking for. So I think we would want that 3rd phase where the clients outright reject legacy txs.
